results.title: Management and top-dressing of pastures
results.brief_description: Stresses the need for pastoralists to maintain their grasslands once established. Shows the use of superphosphate in seeding, also lime and trace elements (in this case, molybdenum). While showing the use of an electric fence for regulated use of pasture, the film warns against overgrazing of the resulting strips. Also explains the need to let grass mature to maximum feed value, and to keep down weeds. Suggests that farmers should grow and store surplus feed.

results.title: A Man of the world: H.H. the Aga Khan
results.creator_credit: Georges Robin, Anthony de Lotbinière and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Pacemakers”.
The Aga Khan is the creator of one of the world’s most dramatic and imaginative development schemes - a planned riviera along 35 miles of Sardinia’s Costa Smeralda. He is also the spiritual leader of more than 12 million Ismaili-Muslims scattered around the world, and a wealthy Parisian, racehourse owner, and Olympic skier. Shows the Aga Khan in a variety of activities. He comments personally, analysing himself and his different faces with the same detached lucidity he brings to all his undertakings.

results.title: Man belongs to the earth
results.creator_credit: Graeme Ferguson, Roman Kroitor and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Deals with the natural environment of United States cities, the desert, the oceans, and the mountains. Shows the dead waste and destruction threatening the environment, and the natural wonders that should be preserved. Presents the problems and some solutions.

results.title: Mammals and their characteristics
results.brief_description: What do the anteater and the seal have in common? They both have some kind of hair and nurse their young. When vertebrates have these two characteristics, they are classified as mammals. The great diversity of mammals is illustrated by representative members of the major groups - carnivores, rodents, ungulates, marsupials and primates.

results.title: Malaya speaks
results.brief_description: An account of the varied services provided by Radio Malaya, which broadcasts programs of entertainment, information, and education in several languages to a listening public of many different races, age-groups and tastes. Besides news, general entertainment and school programs, Radio Malaya broadcasts programs designed to teach people to read, and many programs of special interest to rural communities.

results.title: Malaya posting
results.brief_description: Australian overseas army personnel in Malaya. The contrasts of old and new in this multi-racial Asian country; surrender barracks and the facilities for servicemen’s families; training in jungle warfare, tropical first aid; transport in the jungle; sports and places to visit in leisure time. Australia’s servicemen as ambassadors.

results.title: Malacca: then and now
results.brief_description: Shows Malacca, a small port in Malaya with a long history, including relics of the Hindus, Muslims, Portugese, Dutch and British. Provides glimpses of the religious traditions brought by these peoples, as well as the ancient funeral ceremonies of the Chinese. Claims that Malacca shows how Eastern and Western ways of life can settle down tolerantly together.

results.title: Making shoes (TEFC)
results.brief_description: This film aims to show school children how shoes are manufactured in a modern American factory. It traces the entire process from cutting the leather, through assembly of the various parts of the shoe, to the final polishing and packing.

results.title: Making sense [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Francis Fuchs, Eurfron Gwynne Jones and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Children Growing Up”.
A new born baby has all the five senses needed to perceive his outside world, but making something of it is a slow developmental process. This program constructs situations and experiments to demonstrate how a child sees and makes sense of the world.
